item.title: Valve warns of Steam Deck OLED stock issues due to RAM shortage
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 17, 2026

1 Min Read

Valve has warned it might soon be difficult to purchase the Steam Deck OLED in some regions as a result of memory and storage shortages.

The company has added the following note to the Steam Deck page on the Steam Store to warn prospective buyers: 

"Steam Deck OLED may be out-of-stock intermittently in some regions due to memory and storage shortages. Steam Deck LCD 256GB is no longer in production, and once sold out will no longer be available." 

This is the second time Valve has indicated hardware availability might be impacted by a RAM crisis that is being driven by widespread investment in AI datacenters (thanks, Reuters). 

Earlier this month, the company delayed announcing Steam Machine pricing and shipping details as a result critical component shortages and price hikes. Valve said the situation forced it to "revisit" its shipping schedule and pricing strategy—especially with regards to Steam Machine and Steam Frame hardware. 

Related:Report: Hasbro shutters internal video game studio Atomic Arcade

Other companies such as Sony and Nintendo could also be impacted.

Earlier this week, Bloomberg reported that Sony might delay the next PlayStation until 2028 or 2029 to avoid launching new hardware amid a component shortage. Nintendo, meanwhile, could increase the cost of the Switch 2 next year if the market fails to stabilize.

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.

item.title: Mewgenics sets huge Steam concurrent player record, taking a crown previously worn by Hades 2
item.content:encoded:
Mewgenics, the cat breeding indie hit from the creators of The Binding of Isaac and The End is Nigh, has broken a rather impressive Steam record.

Over the weekend, Mewgenics - which sees players using "tactical" breeding to raise a cat army before sending their feline Frankenstein-like creations into the fray - welcomed 115,428 concurrent players on Steam.

This number probably doesn't mean that much to you on its own, though it is of course an impressive figure. However, Mewgenics' latest concurrent player peak actually means it now has the highest concurrent player count of any roguelike on Steam of all time.

The Steam game with the highest concurrent player count before Mewgenics took the crown was Hades 2, Supergiant's sequel to the incredibly successful Hades and a 2025 Game of the Year nominee.

As you can see via the image below, Hades 2 has a concurrent player peak of 112,947, which was reached five months ago. This means Mewgenics has welcomed 2,481 more concurrent players than Steam's previous roguelike record holder (look at me doing maths early in the morning).

So, yes, Mewgenics is really rather popular, something that has taken co-creators Edmund McMillen and Tyler Glaiel by surprise. On its release, it sold 150k copies in six hours, swiftly making back its development costs. That figure has since increased, and developer Glaiel later revealed Mewgenics had sold half a million units in 36 hours (in the words of Glaiel, "wtf").

The team has already confirmed that Mewgenics DLC is planned, though for when we don't yet know. A console version is also on the cards, but again, we don't know when exactly it may materialise.

If you are one of the many already playing Mewgenics on Steam, be sure to check out our guides. Here is one on the best Mewgenics classes tier list and how to unlock every class to get you started.
